newsitem.title: INDIA: Gates to help India with software development.
newsitem.headline: Gates to help India with software development.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. Chairman Bill Gates said Tuesday that India had the potential to become a computer software superpower and promised help to New Delhi in building its vital communications infrastructure.

"To be a leader in the digital economy of the 21st century, India must invest in basic infrastructure, education and information technology," Gates, who arrived on Monday on a four-day visit, said in a speech on information technology.
"These are the tools which will drive the country into the future and make India an economic and software superpower."
Gates said he discussed India's need for an information infrastructure, especially in telecommunications, with Prime Minister H. D.Deve Gowda over breakfast on Tuesday.
On Monday, he met with Finance Minister P. Chidambaram.
"The key things they are talking about are opportunities for India and for investment," Gates told a news conference.

"Mr. Deve Gowda reiterated to the visitor his government's commitment to provide all the necessary fillip to the Indian scientific community to build on the existing strengths and advantages," the Indian government said in a statement.
"In India there is opportunity to literally create hundreds of thousands of jobs," Gates said later at a business meeting.
Ninety percent of personal computers in the world run on operating software made by Microsoft. "We are working with some experts to extend Windows to Hindi and other languages," Gates said.
India's software industry, which reported sales worth $1.2 billion in 1995/96 (April-March), expects to grow by 50 percent to $1.8 billion in the 1996/97 fiscal that ends this month.
